messages.text: There has been some interest in code that will trap a NaN as it is generated and give some call chain info.  It turns out this is possible with the current versions of Julia, working with the REPL, if and only if there is nothing `print`ed or otherwise `show`n within the NaN trapping or NaN trap handling code (or so it seems).  It would be great to have that restriction eliminated (Julia goes somewhat bonkers, specifics depend on how it is caused, and often, eventually, closes itself) -- it appears to be caused either by some interaction within Ryu or by some interaction in the code that outputs to the screen thereafter), idk what though. Here is some code with an example: <https://gist.github.com/JeffreySarnoff/db217673bc220360dc388136ab170e76|nancatcher.jl>

BFloat16s.jl    (arithmetic, elementary funcs)```

messages.text: Hey there! I am doing a refresher of some algebra concepts while examining computational complexity. I went back through and re-derived an arithmetic sum but what confuses me from a textbook I am reading is the "n" in front of the quantity I circled. Where does this "n" come from? I cannot make it reappear through derivation so I am wondering if it is a degree of freedom or something simple I am missing. Any thoughts?

messages.text: Hey, how do you read this probability: `P(Y | X, K = k)` where `K` is an environmental variable? I would read it as "the probability of Y given X in the presence of K". Does that make sense? And in this case, if K is an environmental variable, how do I mathematically incorporate the variable into, for example, Bayes' Theorem? I could be completely wrong but I appreciate any pointers to get me back on track. :slightly_smiling_face:

I could be completely wrong but I appreciate any pointers to get me back on track.

messages.text: Do you have any general tips for implementing new special functions? I need to evaluate this integral: <https://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=int+1%2Fx+%281+-+x%29%5E%281%2Falpha%29+dx> on arbitrary intervals within about 1e-10 to 1 and while technically existing special functions (incomplete beta function or 2F1 hypergeometric function) can be used, their existing implementations (from GSL) don't handle this parameter range particularly well.

messages.text:
is there any known trick / trap / known bug when copying sparse arrays of BigFloats? I have a weird Heisenbug which I didn't manage to reduce yet, but basically:
```    # x is a sparse vector of BigFloat
    x .= 0
    SparseArrays.dropzeros!(x)
    y = compute_active_set_iterate(active_set)
    @debug "ny $(norm(y))"
    @debug "$(norm(compute_active_set_iterate(active_set)))"
    x .= y
    @debug "$(norm(compute_active_set_iterate(active_set)))"```
the two first debug statements result in the same quantities, but the last one changed.
```compute_active_set_iterate(active_set) = sum(λi * ai for (λi, ai) in active_set)```
`active_set`  is a struct holding two vectors, which is behaving as a vector of tuples

Way back in 2013 or so, we met with Kahan - and he said that all the numerical analysis research boiled down to two practical concerns that programming languages should support - make it easy for people to change rounding modes for their computations, and easily try extended precision. We’ve done reasonably well on supporting different precisions - but the rounding story leaves a lot to be desired.

elements.text: Way back in 2013 or so, we met with Kahan - and he said that all the numerical analysis research boiled down to two practical concerns that programming languages should support - make it easy for people to change rounding modes for their computations, and easily try extended precision. We’ve done reasonably well on supporting different precisions - but the rounding story leaves a lot to be desired.

messages.text: Hopefully LLVM taking it more seriously will help?

elements.text: Hopefully LLVM taking it more seriously will help?

messages.text: Ideally there should be two levels, so one could do `function my_special_fun(x) @setrounding_force RoundNearest ... end` for precision-sensitive code and then `function user_code() @setrounding RoundDown ...` to play with rounding. Same for fastmath, so that eg library code for special functions could force no fast math for a specific function and user code could still enable fastmath at a global level without impacting precision-sensitive functions

elements.text: Ideally there should be two levels, so one could do
function my_special_fun(x) @setrounding_force RoundNearest ... end
for precision-sensitive code and then
function user_code() @setrounding RoundDown ...

to play with rounding. Same for fastmath, so that eg library code for special functions could force no fast math for a specific function and user code could still enable fastmath at a global level without impacting precision-sensitive functions

messages.text:
with function keyword rounding and using `@resetrounding` for your `@setrounding_force`, what is rounding mode used to calculate `y` in these?
```@setrounding RoundDown
  y = sin(x; rounding=RoundUp)
end
@resetrounding RoundDown 
  y = sin(x; rounding=RoundUp)
end```

`x += scalar * (x - v)` ?

elements.text: I'm still hunting an Heisenbug from few weeks ago. Is there a know strong difference for dense vectors `x, v` between
@. x += scalar * (x - v)
and the non-broadcast version
x += scalar * (x - v)
